item.title: Words Hold Worlds
item.description: Part I: Words Hold Worlds on etymology, recursion, and the deep weird of language “In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was a mistake.” —Eliza Morgenstern, Linguistic Aporias (1978) I. The Lie of Meaning Language is a hallucination that pretends it isn’t one. Words don’t mean, not really, they defer meaning. They triangulate it. A word is like a beam of light in fog - it suggests a direction, illuminates particles in its path, but what it ultimately reveals depends on where each observer stands.
